title: LLaSE-G1: Incentivizing Generalization Capability for LLaMA-based Speech Enhancement
author: Boyi Kang (Northwestern Polytechnical University), Xinfa Zhu (Northwestern Polytechnical University), Zihan Zhang (Northwestern Polytechnical University), Zhen Ye (The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology), Mingshuai Liu (Northwestern Polytechnical University), Ziqian Wang (Northwestern Polytechnical University), Yike Zhu (Northwestern Polytechnical University), Guobin Ma (Northwestern Polytechnical University), ..., Lei Xie (Northwestern Polytechnical University)
relevance_why: The methods presented in this paper for speech enhancement directly align with my research interests in audio quality enhancement and generative models, possibly providing innovative techniques for improving generative tasks in speech processing.
background: Speech enhancement involves processing degraded speech signals to recover clear and intelligible audio.
contribution: This paper introduces LLaSE-G1, a LLaMA-based model that unifies multiple speech enhancement tasks, achieving improved performance across noise suppression, packet loss concealment, target speaker extraction, and acoustic echo cancellation.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods were often task-specific, leading to limitations in scalability and generalization across various speech enhancement tasks.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work combines continuous and discrete representations and employs a dual-channel input and output architecture that promotes better generalization without needing task-specific identifiers.

key_innovation: The integration of continuous and discrete features for predicting and reconstructing enhanced speech enhances acoustic preservation while supporting multiple speech tasks within a single model.
real_world_impact: This model has the potential to significantly improve voice communication technologies by providing more robust speech enhancement solutions in real-time applications, enhancing clarity in noisy environments.
limitations: The model operates at a fixed sampling rate of 16,000 Hz, limiting its applicability for full-band audio enhancement.

new_terms.acoustic echo cancellation: **Acoustic Echo Cancellation (AEC)** refers to the process of removing echoes from recorded audio signals to improve clarity.
new_terms.LLaMA: **LLaMA (Large Language Model Meta AI)** refers to a series of language models designed to provide enhanced natural language understanding and generation capabilities.
